Hi,

in addition to cleaning up stuff which might not be cleaned up by the
garbage collection, I use tearDown() for the following
purposes: 

- reset global state to the state before the test:
  Example: 
  Object oldTool;
  protected void setUp() throws Exception {
    super.setUp();
    oldTool = Toolbox.getTool("ThreadFactory");
    Toolbox.registerTool("ThreadFactory",new TestThreadFactory());
  }

  protected void tearDown() throws Exception {
    Toolbox.registerTool("ThreadFactory",oldTool);    
  }

- validate that the tests (and the run objects) did not claim and not
  release resources which they should have.  I think it's kind of smelly
  if threads which have been created during the tests keep running, or
  mutexes have been acquired but not released.  Therefore I introduce
  resource tracking in some test cases.  And the tearDown() is the place
  to validate that claimed resources are in a valid state after the test
  in a generic way. 

What are others doing in their tearDowns?

Cheers,

Arnd.

BTW: Never forget to call the super setUp and tearDown!



>>>>> "Ryan" == Ryan P Ripley <ryan.ripley@...> writes:

    Ryan> Hey Bhanu, Hopefully this helps a bit, my comments are inline
    Ryan> with your questions.

    Ryan> 1) why actuall teardown() method is required.

    Ryan> Teardown() is used to "clean up" any objects created in the
    Ryan> setup().  These objects are generally called fixtures.

    Ryan> Example:

    Ryan> 	void setup() {
    Ryan> 		Class.forName("sun.jdbc.odbc.JdbcOdbcDriver");
    Ryan> 		myDBConnection =
    Ryan> DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:odbc:YourDB");
    Ryan> 		mySqlStatement = myDBConnection.createStatement();
    Ryan> 		myResults = mySqlStatement.executeQuery("select * from
    Ryan> foo");
    Ryan> 	}

    Ryan> 	void tearDown() {
    Ryan> 		myDBConnection.close(); mySqlStatement.close();
    Ryan> 		myResults.close();
    Ryan> 	}

    Ryan> You are basically just cleaning up objects, note: this is not
    Ryan> only limited to db connections, this is just an example usage.

    Ryan> am not making the objects as null. what is the reason.

    Ryan> This is what tearDown() is for.  Object cleanup.  I'm not sure
